titleStmt.title: Some remarks on the Gauss decomposition for quantum group GL q (n) with application to q-bosonization

affiliation.orgName: Sanct Petersburg Institute of Mashine Building

analytic.title: Some remarks on the Gauss decomposition for quantum group GL q (n) with application to q-bosonization

abstract.p: In this letter some properties of the Gauss decomposition of quantum group GL q (n) with application to q-bosonization are considered.

body.p: For investigations of algebraic systems it is often useful to handle with theirs homomorphic realizations by means of simpler systems. The representation of Lie algebra generators by creation and annihilation operators of bosonic oscillators (bosonization) supplies us with a well known example. When we turn to more complicated case of quantum groups and quantum algebras [1] it is natural to change the usual oscillators to deformed ones (q-oscillators) [2-6]. The q-bosonization procedure for quantum algebras was given in [5] with sufficient completeness. However, the situation for quantum groups is quite different. It seems first attempts to this end have been done for the quantum group GL q (n) in the special case q n = 1 only [7-9]. In the general case, q ∈ C\{0}, the examples of q-bosonization were given in [10] and [11] for the GL q (2) and GL q (3) respectively. The attempt to generalize these results to the GL q (n) was undertaken in somewhat complicated fashion in Ref. [12]. The deficiency of this approach [10,12] consists in the use of specific features of the Fock representation for the q-oscillators. As a result, a wide class of non Fock representations (listed, for instance, in [6,13-14]) are excluded from considerations. We must also mention the interesting works [15-16] concerned with the similar problem for the matrix pseudogroups S µ U(n) and used somewhat different form of q-oscillators.

In previous paper [17] we showed that the Gauss decomposition for the GL q (2) suggests q-bosonization in a very simple and pure algebraic way. In this letter we shall give some remarks on general properties of the GL q (n) Gauss decomposition and generalize to this quantum group the algebraic procedure of q-bosonization suggested earlier [17] for the GL q (2). As an illustration of the results we shall consider the GL q (3) case in some details.

div.p: In this section we shall briefly remind some definitions and results of Ref.[1]. The quantum group GL q (n) is defined as an associative unital Calgebra which is generated by n 2 elements T ij subject to the commutation relations T ij T ik = qT ik T ij , T ik T lj = T lj T ik , T ik T lk = qT lk T ik , [T ij , T lk ] = λT ik T lj , (1) where q ∈ C\{0}, λ = q − q −1 , 1 ≤ j < k ≤ n, 1 ≤ i < l ≤ n. In addition, the GL q (n) is endowed with a Hopf algebra structure which introduced by the three maps: a comultiplication ∆ , a counit ǫ and an antipod S [1].
Let T = (T ij ) be n by n matrix of GL q (n) generators (q-matrix). From the commutation relations (1) it follows that the quantum (q-)determinant

p.formula: D q (T ) ≡ det q T = σ (−q) l(σ) n i=1 T iσ(i) (2)

div.p: belongs to the center of the Hopf algebra GL q (n) . In the definition (2) the sum is over all the permutations σ of the set (1, 2, ..., n) , and σ (l) is length of σ . There is additional assumption: det q T = 0 . Supposing the invertibility of D q (T ) , one can calculate the two-sided inverse matrix T

figure.trash: −1 (T −1 ) ik = (D q (T )) −1 (−q) i−k D q (M ik ), where D q (M ik

div.p: ) is a q-determinant of the minor matrix M ik which was obtained from T by removing of the i -th row and k -th column. In the case of GL q (n) the above mentioned coalgebra maps are specified by the formulas
where 1 is the unit matrix and (⊗) refers to the usual matrix multiplication with a tensor product of matrix elements.
In R-matrix approach [1] the equation

encodes commutation relations between generators of a quantum group. In this equation R is a square number matrix of order n 2 , T is a q-matrix and T 1 = T (⊗)1, T 2 = 1(⊗)T . The commutation relations (1) follow from the eq.(4) for the R -matrix corresponding to the Lie algebra sl(n) . The Lie group GL(n) can be defined as an endomorphism group of complex n -dimensional linear space C n . In complete analogy, the quantum group GL q (n) , can be defined by its co-action δ on the related quantum space C n q . This view gives the base of non R -matrix approach to quantum deformations [18-20].

figure.figDesc: 3. Let us consider the Gauss decomposition for the GL q (n) q -matrix T , T = (T ik ) = T L T D T R ,

div.p: where T L = (u ik ) and T R = (z ik ) are upper-and lower-triangular matrices respectively with units at theirs diagonals, and T D = (A ik ), with A ik = δ ik A k , is a diagonal matrix. It is not dificult to express " old " generators T ik in terms of the " new " ones, that is by the elements of the matrices T L , T D and T R . For convinience we shall formulate the main properties of the Gauss decomposition in the following propositions.

figure.head: Proposition 1
figure.figDesc: The commutation relations (1) of the quantum group GL q (n) are fulfilled if the following commutation relations for the elements of the T L , T D and T R matrices hold
figure.trash: A k u ij = q δ ik −δ jk u ij A k , 1 ≤ i, j, k ≤ n; u ik u jk = q δ ik −δ jk +1 u jk u ik , 1 ≤ k ≤ n, i < j; u ik u il = q δ ij −δ ik +1 u ij u ik , 1 ≤ i ≤ n, k < j; u ik u lj = q δ ij −δ kl u lj u ik , i < l, k > j; u ik u lj − q δ ij −δ kl u lj u ik = = λq δ

div.p: ik −δ kl u lk u ij , i < l, k < j; [u ik , z jl ] = [A i , A k ] = 0, 1 ≤ i, j, k, l ≤ n; (5) A k z ij = q δ kj −δ ik z ij A k , 1 ≤ i, j, k ≤ n; z ik z jk = q δ jk −δ ik +1 z jk z ik , 1 ≤ k ≤ n, i < j; z ik z ij = q δ ik −δ ij +1 z ij z ik , 1 ≤ i ≤ n, k < j; z ik z lj = q δ kl −δ ij z lj z ik , i < l, k > j; z ik z lj − q δ kl −δ ij z lj z ik = = λq δ kl −δ ik z lk z ij , i < l, k < j;

figure.head: Proposition 2
figure.figDesc: In terms of the " new " generators the quantum determinant D q (T ) = det q T has the simple form
figure.trash: D q (T ) = detT D = A 11 A 22 · . . . · A nn (6

figure.figDesc: ) and commutes with every element of the matrices T L , T D and T R .

div.p: (For the GL q (2) case the expression (6) was given in [19]). These two propositions can be checked by direct calculations.

Let us denote T = T D T R , and T = T L T D . We would like to stress that the elements each of the matrices (T L , T D , T R , T , and T ) form a set closed under the commutation relations (5) and, thus, define a deformed algebra.

figure.head: Proposition 3 a)
figure.figDesc: The commutation relations between the elements of the ma- trix T ( and T ) are determined by the quantum group equation (4) with the same R-matrix as for GL q (n); b) There is no R-matrix that gives the commutation relations between the elements of the matrix T R (and T L ).

div.p: The first part of this proposition can be proved by direct verification. The attempts of calculation of appropriate R-matrix from the equation (4) in the case of the matrices T R and T L inevitably leads to contradictions. So the algebras defined by the elements of matrices T R and T L , supply us with examples of non R-matrix quantum deformations.

Using the homomorphic property of a comultiplication in the GL q (n) we can define the comultiplications in the algebras connected with each of the matrices T R , T D , T L , T and T . (For the GL q (2) this was done in [21]). However such inherited comultiplication has cumbersome form even for n = 2, 3.

figure.head: Proposition 4
figure.figDesc: The algebra generated by the elements of the matrix T is a Hopf algebra (under the co-operations defined in (3)) and gives us an example of a new quantum group. The same is true for T .
figure.trash: Proposition 5 The map δ(X) = T (⊗)X, δ(x i ) = n k=1 T ik ⊗ x k defines the co-action of the quantum groups T and T on the quantum space C n q . Moreover, the maps δ : C n q → T (⊗)C n q and δ : C n q → T (⊗)C n q are algebra homomorphismes and endow the C n q with a left T -and T -comodule structure, respectively.

div.p: The proof of these two propositions is evident in view of the proposition 3.

figure.trash: a). 4. Let { a † i , a i , N i } and { b † i , b

div.p: i , M i } , i, j = 1 ÷ n be two independent families of mutually commuting q −1 -and q-oscillators [2-6] defined by the relations

figure.trash: a i a † i − q −1 a † i a i = q N i , N i a † i = a † i (N i + 1), N i a i = a i (N i − 1); (7) b i b † i − qb † i b i = q −M i , M i b † i = b † i (M i + 1), M i b i = b i (M i − 1); (8) Define u ik =      0 if i > k 1 if i = k f ik q N ik a † i a k if i < k ; z ik =      0 if i < k 1 if i = k g ik q −M ik b † i b k if i > k; (9) A ik = δ ik q N k −M k ; (10) where N ik = k−1 j=i+1 N j , M ik = i−1 j=k+1 M j , and N ik = 0 (M ik = 0) if i > (k − 2), (i < (k + 2)). Then we have det q T = n i=1 A ii = q N −M , N = n j=1 N j , M = n j=1 M j .
figure.head: Proposition 6
figure.figDesc: The expressions (9-10) satisfy the commutation relations (5) if number coefficients f ik and g ik fulfil the equations f ij f kl = f kj f il i < k < j < l f ij f jk = λq −1 f ik i < j < k ; g ij g kl = g kj g il k > i > l > j g ij g ki = − qλg kj k > j > i ; (11)

div.p: In this case the formulas (9-10) realize q-bosonization of the quantum groups T R , T D , T L and, consequently T , T , GL q (n).
There are several solutions of the equations (11). The symplest one is f ij = λ/q, g ij = −qλ. (12)

It is worth noting that in the present version of GL q (n) q-bosonization 2n independent deformed oscillators are used. On the other hand, following the method of Refs.[10-12] for this purpose n(n-1)/2 q-oscillators are necessary. 5. To illustrate the above results, let us consider the quantum group GL q (3) as an example. The case of GL q (2) studied in [17], is not interesting enough because both the matrices T R and T L contein one non-trivial element only. The Gauss decomposition for the GL q (3) has the form

figure.trash: T = T L T D T R =    1 u v 0 1 w 0 0 1       A 0 0 0 B 0 0 0 C       1 0 0 x 1 0 y z 1    =    A + uBx + vCy uB + vCz vC Bx + wCy B + wCz wC Cy Cz C    , T = T D T R =    A 0 0 Bx B 0 Cy Cz C    , T = T L T D =    A uB vC 0 B wC 0 0 C    .

div.p: The commutation relations for " new " generators follow from (5) [x,u] = [x,v] = [x,w] = 0, [y,u] = [y,v] = [y,w] = 0, [z,u] = [z,v] = [z,w]

figure.trash: = 0, [A,B] = [A,C] = [B,C] = 0; vw = qwv, uv = qvu, quw − wu = λv, xy = qyx, yz = qzy, xz − q −1 zx = λy; uB = qBu, uC = Cu, Au = quA, vC = qCv, vB = Bv, Av = qvA, wC = qCw, wA = wA, Bw = qwB; (13) xB = qBx, xC = Cx, Ax = qxA, yC = qCy, yB = By, Ay = qyA, zC = qCz, zA = Az, Bz = qzB.

div.p: The quantum determinant D q (T ) = ABC commutes with all of " new " generators and, hence, with

figure.trash: T and T . Applying the usual comultiplication ∆(T ) = T (⊗)T in the GL q (3) and denoting Q = y ⊗ v + z ⊗ w + 1 ⊗ 1 ≡ y 1 v 2 + z 1 w 2 + 1; E = 1 + x 1 u 2 − (x 1 v 2 + w 2 )Q −1 (y 1 u 2 + z 1 ); K = (1 − u 2 E −1 L − v 2 Q −1 [y 1 − (y 1 u 2 + z 1 )E −1 L]), where L = [x 1 − (x 1 v 2 + w 2 )Q −1 y 1 ], one can obtain for inheritable comultiplication the following expressions ∆(A) = A 1 KA 2 , ∆(B) = B 1 EB 2 , ∆(C) = C 1 QC 2 ∆(u) = u 1 + A 1 u 2 (B 1 E) −1 − A 1 v 2 Q −1 (y 1 u 2 + z 1 )(B 1 E) −1 , ∆(v) = v 1 + (A 1 v 2 + u 1 B 1 (x 1 v 2 + w 2 ))Q −1 C −1 1 , ∆(w) = w 1 + B 1 (x 1 v 2 + w 2 )Q −1 C −1 1 , ∆(x) = x 2 + (EB 2 ) −1 [x 1 − (x 1 v 2 + w 2 )Q −1 y 1 ]A 2 , ∆(y) = y 2 + C −1 2 Q −1 [y 1 A 2 + (y 1 u 2 + z 1 )B 2 x 2 ], ∆(z) = C −1 2 Q −1 (y 1 u 2 + z 1 )B 2 + z 2 .

div.p: We remaind that A 1 = A⊗1, A 2 = 1⊗A, etc. As it was pointed above, there is " natural " comultiplication together with " inheritable " one in T and T . These two maps are not equivalent because they give obviously different expression for the element C = T 33 . Therefore we deal with new quantum groups.
For the quantum group T the natural comultiplication is given by the relation

figure.trash: ∆( T ) =    A 0 0 Bx B 0 Cx Cz C    (⊗)    A 0 0 Bx B 0 Cy Cz C    = =    A ⊗ A 0 0 Bx ⊗ A + B ⊗ Bx B ⊗ B 0 Cy ⊗ A + Cz ⊗ Bx + C ⊗ C Cz ⊗ B + C ⊗ Cz C ⊗ C    , which yields ∆(A) = A ⊗ A; ∆(B) = B ⊗ B; ∆(C) = C ⊗ C; (14) ∆(x) = x ⊗ B −1 A + 1 ⊗ x, ∆(y) = y ⊗ C −1 A + z ⊗ C −1 B + 1 ⊗ y, ∆(z) = z ⊗ C −1 B + 1 ⊗ z. (15)

div.p: (we assume that the elements A, B, C are invertible). In close analogy, for the quantum group

figure.trash: T besides (13) one has ∆(u) = AB −1 ⊗ u + u ⊗ 1, ∆(v) = AC −1 ⊗ v + uBC −1 ⊗ w + w ⊗ 1, ∆(w) = BC −1 ⊗ w + w ⊗ 1. (16)

div.p: It is not dificult to check that the matrices

   ; T −1 =    A −1 −quA −1 q −1 (uw − v)A −1 0 B −1 −q −1 wB −1 0 0 C −1    , are two sided inverse ones to the T and T respectively. Therefore, the antipodes and counits can be determined in concordance with (3). On element level one has S

figure.trash: (A) = A −1 , S(B) = B −1 , S(C) = C −1 , S(x) = −q 2 A −1 Bx = −xA −1 B, S(z) = −q 2 B −1 Cz = −zB −1 C, S(y) = q 3 A −1 C(xz − qy) = (zx − y)A −1 C; S(u) = −q −1 BuA −1 = −BA −1 u, S(w) = −q −1 CwB −1 = −CB −1 w, S(v) = q −1 C(uw − v)A −1 = CA −1 (uw − v); ε

div.p: All the Hopf algebra axioms [1] with these determinations are satisfied. As a result, the algebras associated with T and T matrices are endowed with a Hopf algebra structure. Therefore, they indeed can be considered as new quantum groups.

figure.figDesc: Now we turn to q-bosonization of the GL q (3) using the solution (12) of the equations (11). So taking three q
figure.trash: −1 -oscillators (7) and three q-oscillators (8) and using (9-10) one gets u = λq −1 a † 1 a 2 , v = λq −1 q N 2 a † 1 a 3 , w = λq −1 a † 2 a 3 , x = −λqb † 2 b 1 , y = −λqq −M 2 b † 3 b 1 , z = −λqb † 3 b 2 , A = q N 1 −M 1 , B = q N 2 −M 2 , A = q N 3 −M 3 . For the original GL q (3)-generators this gives T 11 = q N 1 −M 1 − qλ 2 q N 2 −M 2 a † 1 a 2 b † 2 b 1 + q N 3 −M 3 a † 1 a 3 b † 3 b 1 , T 12 = λq −1 a † 1 a 2 q N 2 −M 2 − λqq N 2 +N 3 −M 3 a † 1 a 3 b † 3 b 2 , T 13 = λq −1 a † 1 a 3 q N 2 +N 3 −M 3 , T 21 = −λq q N 2 −M 2 b † 2 b 1 + λq N 3 −M 3 −M 2 a † 2 a 3 b † 3 b 1 , T 22 = q N 2 −M 2 − λ 2 q N 3 −M 3 a † 2 a 3 b † 3 b 2 , T 23 = λq N 3 −M 3 a † 2 a 3 , T 31 = −λqq N 3 −M 2 −M 3 b † 3 a 1 , T 32 = −λqq N 3 −M 3 b † 3 b 2 , T 33 = q N 3 −M 3 .
